title: One of the main characteristics of cloud computing is that resources are elastic. What does that mean?

options.title: Resources can be allocated automatically.
When customers need more resources, they can get more. When they need less, they can scale back.
You can quickly get more resources when you need them.
You share resources from a large pool that enables economies of scale.

title: You are considering deploying a solution by using containers on Google Cloud. What Google Cloud solution provides a managed compute platform with native support for containers?

options.title: Cloud Functions
Google Kubernetes Engine clusters
Compute Engine autoscaling groups
Container Registry

title: What Identity and Access Management (IAM) hierarchy structure is best for building an application in Google Cloud?

options.title: Create a new organization node for the project, then create all projects and resources inside the new organization node.
Create new projects and resources inside departmental folders for the resources needed, organized by the component applications.
Create a new folder inside your organization node, then create projects inside that folder for the resources.
Create new projects for each of the component applications, then create folders inside those for the resources.

title: You are developing a new product for a customer and need to be mindful of cost and resources. What Google Cloud tools can be used to ensure costs stay manageable before consumption gets too high?

options.title: Configure the billing account at the product folder level in the resource hierarchy.
Set up budgets and alerts at the project level.
Configure the billing account for each project associated with the product.
Configure quotas and limits for each product folder.

title: What is significant about the topmost layer in a container? Choose two options.

options.title: Reading from or writing to the topmost layer requires special software libraries.
The topmost layer's contents are ephemeral. When the container is deleted, the contents are lost.
An application running in a container can only modify the topmost layer.
Reading from or writing to the topmost layer requires special privileges.

title: When using Kubernetes, you must describe the desired state you want, and Kubernetes's job is to make the deployed system conform to that desired state and keep it there despite failures. What is the name of this management approach?

options.title: Virtualization
Imperative configuration
Declarative configuration
Containerization

title: What is the name for the computers in a Google Kubernetes Engine cluster that run workloads?

options.title: Container images
Control planes
Nodes
Containers

title: Google Kubernetes Engine offers two modes of operation: Autopilot and Standard mode. Which one of the options below is a use case for using Standard mode.

options.title: You require SSH access to nodes.
You want machine types based on workloads.
You want to avoid cluster configuration.
You want to only pay for Pods and not nodes.

title: You want to deploy multiple copies of an application in an effort to load balance traffic. How should you deploy Pods to production to achieve this?

options.title: Create a Service manifest for the LoadBalancer that specifies the number of replicas you want to run.
Create separate named Pod manifests for each instance of the application, and deploy as many as you need.
Deploy the Pod manifest multiple times until you achieve the number of replicas required.
Create a deployment manifest that specifies the number of replicas that you want to run

title: When designing an application, you want the containers to be located as close to each other as possible in order to minimize latency. Which design decision helps meet this requirement?

options.title: Place the containers in the same Pod.
Place the containers in the same cluster.
Give the containers the same labels.
Place the containers in the same Namespace.
